page.title: 1976 Conference of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe

revision.text:
{{Coord|52|31|21|N|13|24|48|E|display=title}} {{Infobox summit meeting | summit_name = Conference of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe | other_titles = | image = Stamps of Germany (DDR) 1976, MiNr 2146.jpg | alt = East German stamp commemorating the conference | caption = East German stamp commemorating the conference | country = [[German Democratic Republic]] | date = June 29–30, 1976 | venues = [[Park Inn Berlin|Interhotel Stadt Berlin]], [[Alexanderplatz]], [[East Berlin]] | participants = {{flatlist| ;Eastern Europe : [[Leonid Brezhnev|Brezhnev]] : [[Nicolae Ceauşescu|Ceauşescu]] : [[Edward Gierek|Gierek]] : [[Gustáv Husák|Husák]] : [[Erich Honecker|Honecker]] : [[János Kádár|Kádár]] : [[Josip Broz Tito|Tito]] : [[Todor Zhivkov|Zhivkov]] }}{{flatlist| ;Western Europe : [[Santiago Carrillo|Carrillo]] : [[Enrico Berlinguer|Berlinguer]] : [[George Marchais|Marchais]] : [[Alvaro Cunhal|Cunhal]] }} | follows = [[1969 International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties]] | precedes = | website = | keypoints = }} The '''Conference of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe''' was an international meeting of [[communist party|communist parties]], held in the city of [[East Berlin]], capital of the communist-governed [[East Germany]], on 29–30 June 1976.''[https://books.google.com/books?id=BKXsAAAAMAAJ Comparative communist foreign policy, 1965-1976]''. Rand Corporation, 1976. p. 99Loeber, Dietrich André. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=69woVmAqZfgC&pg=PA226 Ruling Communist Parties and Their Status Under Law]''. Dordrecht [u.a.]: Nijhoff, 1986. p. 226 In all, 29 parties from all [[Europe]] (except [[Albania]], [[Iceland]] and some [[European microstates|microstates]]) participated in the conference.Braun, Aurel. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=AzFpAAAAMAAJ Romanian Foreign Policy Since 1965: The Political and Military Limits of Autonomy]''. New York: Praeger, 1978. p. 41 The conference highlighted several important changes in the European communist movement. It exhibited the declining influence of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] and a widening gap between the independent and orthodox camps amongst European communist parties, with the ascent of a new political trend, [[Eurocommunism]].Sharma, Prem Mohan. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=C4sx5JYpR_IC&pg=PA106 Politics of Peace and UN General Assembly]''. New Delhi: Abhinav Publications, 1977. p. 106 ==Background== Held in [[Moscow]], the [[1969 International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties]] was a debacle for its [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] hosts, as several parties (most notably the [[Workers Party of Korea]] and the [[Workers Party of Vietnam]]), had boycotted the event, whilst others had used the meeting as a platform to condemn the Soviet Union's [[Prague Spring|1968 military intervention in Czechoslovakia]].Shore, Cris. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=BliKAAAAMAAJ Italian Communism: The Escape from Leninism : an Anthropological Perspective]''. London: Pluto Press, 1990. p. 113 Following the 1969 colloquium, proposals were put forward for another international conference, with the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] hoping to regain its lost prestige through such an event. However, many constituents of the world communist movement, primarily in Asia but also in Europe, were opposed to the holding of another international conference.Wishnick, Elizabeth. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=pq0P8G4O8M8C&pg=PA52 Mending Fences: The Evolution of Moscow's China Policy from Brezhnev to Yeltsin]''. Seattle [u.a.]: University of Washington Press, 2001. p. 52 Rather than holding a meeting representing the global communist movement, by the mid-1970s, most of the main communist parties in Europe had expressed an interest in holding a specifically European conference instead. During that decade, several political changes had occurred in Western Europe that various communist parties wanted to take advantage of; notably, Spain and Portugal had overseen the transition from right-wing military juntas to [[representative democracy|representative democracies]], while the parliamentary isolation faced by the French and Italian communist parties had come to an end.Bracke, Maud. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=hZYCNkngLe8C&pg=PA347 Which Socialism, Whose Détente?: West European Communism and the Czechoslovak Crisis, 1968]''. Budapest: Central European University Press, 2007. p. 324 During the 1970s, a new theoretical trend had emerged in several Western European communist parties that came to be known as [[Eurocommunism]]. Rejecting the domination of the Soviet Communist Party, it emphasized the development of theories and practices that were more applicable to Western Europe. The Soviet government disliked this Eurocommunist trend, and hoped that through holding a conference, they could achieve a document constituting a ''de facto'' charter of the European communist movement which would maintain their dominant role. Soviet discourse did at the time emphasize the importance of a united communist movement across the continent, denying differences between parties and labelling the distinction between Eastern and Western Europe as artificial.''[https://books.google.com/books?id=d2STAAAAIAAJ Eurocommunism between East and West]''. Bloomington: Indiana University press, 1980. p. 7 ==Preparations== There was a prolonged process of preparation before the conference convened. Intense negotiations took place between October 1974 and June 1976, although accounts vary as to how many meetings actually took place, with claims ranging from 12 to 16. The first preparatory meeting was held in [[Warsaw]], capital of [[Poland]]. Throughout the preparatory process, the Spanish, Italian, French, Romanian and Yugoslav parties pressed for recognition of the autonomy of each party, whilst the Czechoslovaks, Polish, Hungarians, Bulgarians and East Germans rallied to the defense of Soviet positions.Valdez, Jonathan C. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vXS9iL543D8C&pg=PA71 Internationalism and the Ideology of Soviet Influence in Eastern Europe]''. Cambridge u.a: Cambridge University Press, 1993. p. 71Dougherty, James E., and Diane K. Pfaltzgraff. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=OlQYAAAAIAAJ Eurocommunism and the Atlantic Alliance]''. Cambridge, Mass: Institute for Foreign Policy Analysis, 1977. p. 33 The disagreements during the preparatory process delayed the conference for a year. At an early stage, an agreement was reached that any document approved by the conference would have to be adopted by consensus. Another agreement was that the agenda of the conference would be limited to themes relating to peace, security, disarmament and the struggle for social progress. The last two editorial meetings for the drafting of the conference resolution were held in East Berlin on June 10–11 and June 24, 1976.Leonhard, Wolfgang. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=1NwEAQAAIAAJ Eurocommunism: Challenge for East and West]''. New York: Holt, Rinehart, and Winston, 1978. p. 145 Unlike the previous International Meetings of Communist and Workers Parties, the [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia]] participated in the preparations and the conference (however, the [[Party of Labour of Albania]] did not participate).''[https://books.google.com/books?id=bSJtQwAACAAJ Europas väg till socialismen]''. Stockholm: Arbetarkultur, 1980. pp. 17-18 The [[Communist Party of Greece (Interior)]], a Eurocommunist splinter group, was barred from participating in the conference.Clogg, Richard. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=kXm-cEJkvy4C&pg=PA178 Parties and Elections in Greece: The Search for Legitimacy]''. Durham: Duke University Press, 1987. p. 178 The Icelandic [[People's Alliance (Iceland)|People's Alliance]] boycotted the conference.Tannahill, R. Neal. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=teYEAQAAIAAJ The Communist Parties of Western Europe: A Comparative Study]''. Westport: Greenwood Press, 1978. p. 80 Parallel to the conference preparations, the [[Italian Communist Party]] organized two bilateral events with its two main Eurocommunist counterparts; a meeting with the [[Communist Party of Spain]] in [[Livorno]] in July 1975 and a summit with the [[French Communist Party]] in Rome in the summer 1976.Dunphy, Richard. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8ILv-HBTlf8C&pg=PA26 Contesting Capitalism?: Left Parties and European Integration]''. Manchester [u.a.]: Manchester University Press, 2004. p. 26 The Eurocommunists were not a solid bloc, and sharp differences between the parties were manifested during the preparatory process. The French party, whilst criticizing the lack of civil liberties in the Soviet Union, was hesitant to give up [[proletarian internationalism]] for the concept of international solidarity proposed by the Italians.Machin, Howard. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=6-8NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA95 National communism in Western Europe]''. London: Methuen, 1983. p. 95 Differences on how to analyze the situation in Portugal following the [[Carnation Revolution]] divided the French and Italian parties. The French voiced their support for the strategy of the Portuguese Communist Party whilst the Italians publicly criticized the Portuguese party.Bracke, Maud. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=hZYCNkngLe8C&pg=PA347 Which Socialism, Whose Détente?: West European Communism and the Czechoslovak Crisis, 1968]''. Budapest: Central European University Press, 2007. p. 347 ==Debates and document== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-R0629-0114, Berlin, Alexanderplatz, Hotel "Stadt Berlin".jpg|thumb|300px|The venue of the conference, the [[Park Inn Berlin|Interhotel Stadt Berlin]]]]Albeit without direct polemical exchanges, the speeches made at the conference showed diversity between positions the communist parties present. In their speeches, [[Santiago Carrillo]], [[Enrico Berlinguer]] and [[George Marchais]] decried aspects of the Soviet political system. Berlinguer stated that West European communists favoured a democratic state, political pluralism, freedom of expression, free [[trade unions]] and religious freedoms.Ouimet, Matthew J. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=aFSwrUcuDWsC&pg=PA85 The Rise and Fall of the Brezhnev Doctrine in Soviet Foreign Policy]''. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2003. pp. 85-87 In his address to the assembled delegates, the Yugoslav leader [[Josip Broz Tito]] stated that "[c]ommunists must accept different roads in the struggle for socialism, independence, equality and non-interference in internal affairs". The Romanian leader [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]] also voiced support for principles of independence of individual parties and non-interference.Leonhard, Wolfgang. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=1NwEAQAAIAAJ Eurocommunism: Challenge for East and West]''. New York: Holt, Rinehart, and Winston, 1978. pp. 146-147 Other participants that argued for the Eurocommunist cause at the conference were [[Lars Werner]] from Sweden, [[Gordon McLennan (politician)|Gordon McLennan]] from Britain, [[Ermenegildo Gasperoni]] from San Marino and, to a lesser extent, the Finnish Communist Party chief [[Aarne Saarinen]]. On the other hand, there were also interventions from other delegates whom re-affirmed their adherence to the line of the Soviet party. The Bulgarian communist leader [[Todor Zhivkov]], in his intervention, took a firmer stand than the Soviets in upholding the notion of general laws of socialist development (as opposed to the idea that each party should develop its own way of building socialism), denouncing [[Marxist revisionism|revisionism]] and underlining the dual responsibility of the individual communist party (both to its own people and the world communist movement). [[Gustáv Husák]] of Czechoslovakia and the East German host, [[Erich Honecker]], were also amongst the prominent spokespersons of the orthodox camp. Other parties that voiced their support for the Soviets, in varying degrees, were the Greek, Portuguese, West German, Luxembourgish, Danish, West Berlin, Turkish, Norwegian and Austrian parties. [[File:Positions of European Communist Parties at the 1976 Berlin Conference.png|thumb|left|300px|Positions of the European communist parties at the 1976 Berlin Conference:
Red = Orthodox or Pro-Soviet camp
Green = Eurocommunist or Independent camp
Blue = Neutral group
Grey = Boycott]] The Soviet party leader [[Leonid Brezhnev]] adopted a more conciliatory tone than his orthodox colleagues. He urged the conference to reaffirmation its commitment to [[proletarian internationalism]], but without references to dual responsibility and mutual assistance (which had been cornerstones of Soviet discourse on the subject).Valdez, Jonathan C. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vXS9iL543D8C&pg=PA75 Internationalism and the Ideology of Soviet Influence in Eastern Europe]''. Cambridge u.a: Cambridge University Press, 1993. pp. 75-77 [[Edward Gierek]] of Poland and [[János Kádár]] of Hungary also placed themselves within the orthodox camp in their speeches to the conference, but kept a lower profile and expressed certain individual nuances. Apart from the main antagonists at the Berlin meeting, there was also a grouping of parties that were reluctant to choose either the Eurocommunist or the orthodox side. This grouping included the Cypriot, Belgian, Dutch, Irish and Swiss delegates. The final document of the conference was titled "For Peace, Security, Cooperation and Social Progress in Europe".''[https://books.google.com/books?id=UqrS4U6VfYEC&pg=PA9 The Language of Foreign Affairs]''. Department of State Library, 1978. p. 9 The document contained several novelties compared to previous practices in the world communist movement. One of the most prominent features of the document was the recognition of the principle of "equality and independence of all communist parties and their right to decide their own policies without external interference". The Soviet party had thus, at least in theory, conceded to the Eurocommunist demands for the principle of non-interference in the affairs of other parties. The document carried no mention of [[Marxism-Leninism]], instead there was a reference to the 'great ideas' of [[Karl Marx]], [[Friedrich Engels]] and [[V. I. Lenin]]. References to 'proletarian internationalism' were substituted with the term 'international solidarity'. Moreover, the document stated that fraternal criticism between communist parties would not constitute anti-communism (implying that criticism of Soviet policies would not be considered as 'anti-Sovietism', as the official Soviet discourse had argued).Urban, Joan Barth. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8HDEhJQON1AC&pg=PA275 Moscow and the Italian Communist Party: From Togliatti to Berlinguer]''. London: Tauris, 1986. p. 275 The document was not approved through signature or a vote, it was simply issued, a fact later criticized by the Yugoslavs. The conference also endorsed the [[Helsinki Accords|Helsinki process]] and [[International human rights instruments|international human rights covenants]].Thomas, Daniel Charles. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=UPym2WAzDuEC&pg=PA182 The Helsinki Effect: International Norms, Human Rights, and the Demise of Communism]''. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2001. p. 182 Unlike the declaration of the 1969 meeting, the Berlin conference document did not contain any condemnation of China. The Soviets had pushed for a condemnation of China ahead of the conference, but the Yugoslavs, the French and the Italians resisted these moves.Ross, George. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QpRVV071D0wC&pg=PA251 Workers and Communists in France: From Popular Front to Eurocommunism]''. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1982. p. 251Kapur, Harish. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=wmDEYFCU03QC&pg=PA210 The End of Isolation: China After Mao]''. Dordrecht: Martinus Nijhoff, 1985. p. 210 At the Berlin conference, the French Communist Party rejected the possibility of holding future conferences on the same lines. ==Aftermath== The verbatim of the speeches at the conference were presented in full in ''[[Neues Deutschland]]'', the central organ of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany, whilst the more critical aspects were censored out in the reports in the Soviet newspaper ''[[Pravda]]''. In particular the speech of Carrillo was very difficult for the Soviets to digest.In his speech to the conference, Carrillo stated that "The past and present sufferings of our parties and the time spent in the catacombs have created among our rank and file an alloy made out of scientific socialism and a kind of mysticism based on sacrifice and a sense of predestination. We have built a new kind of church with our own martyrs and prophets. Moscow, where our dreams first began to come true, was for a long time a kind of Rome for us. We spoke of the Great October Socialist Revolution as if it were our Christmas. This was the period of our infancy. Today we have grown up." See East, Roger. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=IHsEAQAAIAAJ Communist and Marxist Parties of the World]'' (Harlow, Essex: Longman [u.a.], 1990. p. 559). ''Pravda'' sought to portray the conference as a victory for proletarian internationalism and communist unity, downplaying the divisions that had appeared at the meeting. Other Socialist Bloc newspapers also censored the speeches from the conference. Following the Berlin conference the Eurocommunists would step up their critiques of Soviet policies further. They began to foster relations with dissidents inside the Socialist Bloc and, occasionally, defended them against state repression. Soviet party at times responded in kind to Eurocommunist critiques through veiled ideological counter-accusations.Boggs, Carl, and David Plotke. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=YLpeehsfuMwC&pg=PA33 The Politics of Eurocommunism: Eclipse of the Bolshevik Legacy in the West]''. Montreal: Black Rose Books, 1980. pp. 33, 313Urban, Joan Barth. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8HDEhJQON1AC&pg=PA283 Moscow and the Italian Communist Party: From Togliatti to Berlinguer]''. London: Tauris, 1986. p. 283 A notable counter-attack by the orthodox camp was an article by Zhivkov in ''[[Problems of Peace and Socialism]]'' in December 1976, which decried Eurocommunism as an anti-Soviet 'subversion against proletarian internationalism'.Garthoff, Raymond L. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mGG-x_tuNUcC&pg=PA546 Détente and Confrontation: American-Soviet Relations from Nixon to Reagan]''. Washington, D.C.: Brookings Inst, 1994. p. 546 The Yugoslav party on its side claimed that the Soviets had corrupted the conference documentation, that the Soviets had tried to portray a greater degree of unity between the parties than what had actually been the case at the conference. In April 1980 a new European conference was held in [[Paris]], but under different terms. The principle of consensus was gone at the Paris conference, and the Italian, Romanian, Spanish, Yugoslav, Icelandic, British, Dutch and Sammarinese communist parties boycotted the event.Machin, Howard. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=6-8NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA36 National communism in Western Europe]''. London: Methuen, 1983. p. 36Urban, Joan Barth. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8HDEhJQON1AC&pg=PA311 Moscow and the Italian Communist Party: From Togliatti to Berlinguer]''. London: Tauris, 1986. p. 311 The French Communist Party, co-sponsors of the meeting together with the Polish United Workers Party, rejected the notion that the Paris meeting would have been of a similar kind as the Berlin conference as no common positions on strategy had been approved.Machin, Howard. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=6-8NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA104 National communism in Western Europe]''. {{yearbox | in?=in politics | cp=20th century | c=21st century | cf=22nd century | yp1=2013 | yp2=2014 | yp3=2015 | year=2016 | ya1=2017 | ya2=2018 | ya3=2019 | dp3=1970s | dp2=1980s | dp1=1990s | d=2010–2019{{!}}2010s | dn1=2010s | dn2=2020s | dn3=2030s |}}
These are some of the notable events relating to [[politics]] in 2016.
==Events==
===January=== * [[January 3]] – Following [[2016 attack on the Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran|the fallout]] caused by the [[Nimr al-Nimr#Execution and reaction against|execution of Nimr al-Nimr]], [[Iran]] ends its [[Iran–Saudi Arabia relations|diplomatic relations]] with [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Agence France-Presse on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/AFP/status/683742509407801346|website=Twitter|accessdate=2016-01-03}}</ref> * [[January 16]] – The [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] announces that Iran has adequately dismantled [[Iran and nuclear weapons|its nuclear weapons program]], allowing the [[United Nations]] to lift sanctions immediately.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran nuclear deal: 'New chapter' for Tehran as sanctions end|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35336707|date=2016-01-17|accessdate=2016-01-17|work=BBC}}</ref>
===February=== * [[February 7]] – [[North Korea]] launches a long-range rocket into space, violating multiple UN treaties and prompting condemnation from around the world.<ref>{{cite news |title=North Korea fires long-range rocket despite warnings |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-35515207 |date=2016-02-07 |website=BBC News |accessdate=2016-02-12}}</ref>
===March=== * [[March 21]] – The 44th [[President of the United States]], [[Barack Obama]], visits [[Cuba]], marking the first time a sitting US president has visited the island nation since president [[Calvin Coolidge]] visited in 1928.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/happened-time-us-president-visited-cuba/story?id=27689730|title=The Last Time an American President Visited Cuba|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2016-03-22|website=ABC News|access-date=2017-06-24}}</ref>
===June=== * [[June 23]] – The [[United Kingdom]] votes [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|in a referendum]] to leave the [[European Union]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/25/world/europe/britain-brexit-european-union-referendum.html|title=Britain Votes to Leave the European Union|last=Erlanger|first=Steven|date=2016-06-23|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-06-24}}</ref> * [[June 28]] – [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]] is suspected to be responsible for [[2016 Atatürk Airport attack|attacking]] [[Istanbul Atatürk Airport|Atatürk Airport]] in [[Istanbul]], killing 45 and injuring around 230.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-36658187|title=Istanbul Ataturk airport attack: 41 dead and more than 230 hurt|date=2016-06-29|website=BBC News|accessdate=2017-05-01}}</ref>
===July=== * [[July 12]] – The [[Philippines]] wins the [[Philippines v. China|arbitration case]] they filed at the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] regarding the legality of [[China]]'s "[[Nine-Dash Line]]" claim over the [[South China Sea]] under the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Tom|last2=Holmes|first2=Oliver|last3=Bowcott|first3=Owen|title=Beijing rejects tribunal's ruling in South China Sea case|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/12/philippines-wins-south-china-sea-case-against-china|accessdate=2016-07-13|work=[[The Guardian]]|issn=0261-3077|date=2016-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Perlez|first1=Jane|title=Tribunal Rejects Beijing's Claims in South China Sea|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/world/asia/south-china-sea-hague-ruling-philippines.html?_r=0|accessdate=2016-07-13|work=[[The New York Times]]|issn=0362-4331|date=2016-07-12}}</ref> * [[July 13]] – [[Theresa May]] is declared [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]].
===August=== * [[August 31]] – The [[Federal Senate|Brazilian Senate]] votes (61–20) to [[Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff|impeach]] the [[President of Brazil]] [[Dilma Rousseff]]. The [[Vice President of Brazil]], [[Michel Temer]], who had assumed the presidential powers and duties as Acting President of [[Brazil]] during Rousseff's suspension, takes office for the remainder of her term.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brazil impeachment: Key questions|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36028117|accessdate=2016-09-05|publisher=BBC News|date=2016-08-31}}</ref>
===September=== * [[September 3]] – The US and China, together responsible for 40% of the world's [[Greenhouse gas|carbon emissions]], both formally joined the [[Paris Agreement|Paris global climate agreement]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-37265541|title=Paris climate deal: US and China announce ratification|publisher=BBC News|date=2016-09-03|accessdate=2016-09-03}}</ref> * [[September 9]] – The government of [[North Korea]] conducts its fifth and reportedly biggest [[September 2016 North Korean nuclear test|nuclear test]]. World leaders condemn the act, with [[South Korea]] calling it "maniacal recklessness".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/09/08/asia/north-korea-seismic-activity/|title=North Korea claims successful test of nuclear warhead|last=Hunt|first=Katie|last2=Kwon|first2=K.J.|last3=Hanna|first3=Jason|publisher=CNN|date=2016-09-09|accessdate=2016-09-09}}</ref>
===October=== * [[October 13]] – The [[Maldives]] announces its decision to withdraw from the [[Commonwealth of Nations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foreign.gov.mv/v2/en/media-center/news/article/1999 |title=The Maldives decides to leave the Commonwealth; commits to continue with its international engagement |publisher=Maldivian Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=2016-10-13 |accessdate=2016-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161014060506/http://www.foreign.gov.mv/v2/en/media-center/news/article/1999 |archivedate=October 14, 2016 }}</ref>
===November=== * [[November 8]] – [[Donald Trump]] wins the [[United States presidential election, 2016|United States presidential election]].
===December=== * [[December 19]] – [[Andrei Karlov]], the Russian ambassador to Turkey, is [[Assassination of Andrei Karlov|assassinated]] in [[Ankara]].<ref name="BBC-Turkey">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-38369962|title=Russian ambassador to Turkey Andrei Karlov shot dead in Ankara|date=2016-12-19|publisher=BBC news}}</ref> * [[December 23]] – The [[United Nations Security Council]] adopts [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 2334|Resolution 2334]] condemning "[[Israeli settlement]]s in [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian territories occupied since 1967]]".<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news|title=Israeli settlements: UN Security Council calls for an end|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-38421026|accessdate=2016-12-27|work=BBC News|date=2016-12-23}}</ref>

page.title: 2017 vote of no confidence in the government of Mariano Rajoy

revision.text:
{{Infobox news event | title = 2017 vote of no confidence in the government of Mariano Rajoy | image = | image_size = | caption = | date = 13–14 June 2017 | place = [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]], [[Spain]] | cause = The unveiling of a massive string of corruption scandals affecting the [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] (PP) | participants = {{flatlist| *[[People's Party (Spain)|PP]] *[[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party|PSOE]] *[[Unidos Podemos]] *[[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Cs]] *[[Republican Left of Catalonia|ERC]] *[[Catalan European Democratic Party|PDeCAT]] *[[Basque Nationalist Party|PNV]] *[[Coalició Compromís|Compromís]] *[[EH Bildu]] *[[Navarrese People's Union|UPN]] *[[Canarian Coalition|CCa]] *[[Asturias Forum|FAC]] *[[New Canaries|NCa]] }} | outcome = Motion rejected }} A [[vote of no confidence]] in the Spanish [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] [[Rajoy government#Second Rajoy government (2016–present)|Government]] of [[Mariano Rajoy]] was announced on 27 April 2017 and held on 13–14 June. The motion of no confidence was formally registered on 19 May by [[Unidos Podemos]] after a massive corruption case involving high-ranking PP officials unveiled maneuvers from the Rajoy government to influence the [[judicial system]] in order to cover-up the scandal.<ref>{{cite news |last=Torres |first=Diego |date=18 May 2017 |title=Spain’s never-ending corruption problem |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/spain-corruption-pp-rajoy-never-ending-problem-graft-ignacio-gonzalez/ |work=Politico |location=<!--Not stated--> |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Riveiro |first=Aitor |date=19 May 2017 |title=Irene Montero: "Las fuerzas que voten 'no' a la moción de censura estarán sosteniendo al Gobierno" |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Irene-Montero-censura-sosteniendo-Gobierno_0_645335722.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref> This was the third vote of no confidence held in Spain since the country's [[Spanish transition to democracy|transition to democracy]], after the unsuccessful 1980 and 1987 no confidence votes.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rodríguez Arroyo |first=Jorge |date=27 April 2017 |title=La moción de censura de Podemos, la tercera de la democracia |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/04/27/actualidad/1493288931_051672.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref> Votes of no confidence in Spain are [[Constructive vote of no confidence|constructive]], meaning that confidence from a [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]] may only be withdrawn if a positive majority for a prospective successor exists. Opposition parties [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party|PSOE]], [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Ciudadanos]] and [[Basque Nationalist Party|PNV]] announced their opposition to any candidate proposed by Podemos, meaning that the motion was unlikely to succeed.<ref name="censure1">{{cite news |last=Torres |first=Diego |date=27 April 2017 |title=Podemos divides opposition with Rajoy no-confidence motion |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/spain-corruption-rajoy-pp-podemos-divides-opposition-with-no-confidence-motion/ |work=Politico |location=<!--Not stated--> |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="oppositiontocensure">{{cite news |last1=Garea |first1=Fernando |last2=Díez |first2=Anabel |date=27 April 2017 |title=PSOE, Ciudadanos y PNV rechazan la moción de censura que propone Podemos |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/04/27/actualidad/1493283872_576593.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
The motion was defeated on 14 June 2017, gathering the support of Unidos Podemos, [[Coalició Compromís|Compromís]], [[Republican Left of Catalonia|ERC]] and [[EH Bildu]] (for a total of 82 favourable votes), the opposition of PP, Ciudadanos, [[Navarrese People's Union|UPN]], [[Canarian Coalition|CCa]] and [[Asturias Forum|FAC]] (170 votes against) and the abstentions of PSOE, [[Catalan European Democratic Party|PDeCAT]], PNV and [[New Canaries|NCa]] (97).<ref name="MotionResult"/>
This was the first motion of no confidence to be registered in Spain by a parliamentary group different than one of the two largest ones.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rodríguez-Pina |first=Gloria |date=27 April 2017 |title=Qué es una moción de censura y por qué no prosperará la de Podemos |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/04/27/actualidad/1493288856_961028.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:(Mariano Rajoy) Copa de Navidad PP Madrid (39257644232) (cropped).jpg|175px|thumb|upright|The motion of no confidence was tabled after a massive string of scandals shook [[Mariano Rajoy]]'s [[People's Party (Spain)|party]] and [[Second Rajoy Government|government]].]] The [[Second Rajoy Government]] was sworn into office on 31 October 2016, after a [[2015–16 Spanish government formation|ten-month political deadlock and two general elections]] and the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]]'s (PSOE) decision not to block [[Mariano Rajoy]]'s investiture bid. However, the resulting government was a [[Minority government|minority]] one, and throughout the ensuing months it struggled to get its bills passed into law.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=16 March 2017 |title=El Congreso tumba por primera vez un decreto ley del PP al derribar la reforma de la estiba |url=http://www.europapress.es/nacional/noticia-congreso-tumba-primera-vez-decreto-ley-pp-derribar-reforma-estiba-20170316131658.html |language=Spanish |work=Europa Press |location=Madrid |access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref> Furthermore, the ruling [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] (PP) came under increasing political pressure after a political scandal in [[Region of Murcia|Murcia]] forced [[President of the Region of Murcia|regional President]] [[Pedro Antonio Sánchez]] to resign, having been accused of several corruption crimes.<ref>{{cite news |last=García |first=Luis |date=4 April 2017 |title=Dimite el presidente de Murcia Pedro Antonio Sánchez |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20170404/421442385580/pedro-antonio-sanchez-presidente-de-murcia-dimision.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref>
In April 2017, after only five months into its term, the PP was shaken by a succession of events that smashed attempts to relaunch the party's image. Just as Prime Minister Rajoy was called to testify as witness at the [[Gürtel case|Gürtel graft trial]], a new, massive case of alleged corruption was unveiled (dubbed as "Lezo"), joining the already ongoing investigations into the Púnica and Gürtel scandals. Operation Lezo resulted in the arrest of former [[President of the Community of Madrid]] [[Ignacio González González|Ignacio González]], who was accused of diverting millions of euros from the public treasury into tax havens and to pay off his party's debts during his tenure as regional premier.<ref>{{cite news |last=Casqueiro |first=Javier |date=20 April 2017 |title=Spanish PM Rajoy on the ropes as corruption scandals hit ruling party |url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2017/04/20/inenglish/1492671101_227503.html |work=El País |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Recuero |first=Marisa |date=21 April 2017 |title=La trama de González desvió 23,3 millones de "dinero madrileño" a cuentas en paraísos fiscales |url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2017/04/21/58f9fa8de5fdea26658b463a.html |language=Spanish |work=El Mundo |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Urreiztieta |first=Esteban |date=22 April 2017 |title=Ignacio González "saneó" el PP con dinero público coincidiendo con su llegada a la Presidencia en Madrid |url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2017/04/22/58fb621ce5fdea8a028b458c.html |language=Spanish |work=El Mundo |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> The scope of the new scandal reached heights never seen in Spanish politics before. Several companies (namely [[Obrascón Huarte Lain|OHL]], [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]], [[Indra Sistemas|Indra]] and [[Canal de Isabel II]], among others), suspect of having illegally financed the [[People's Party of the Community of Madrid|Madrilenian PP]], had their headquarters in Spain registered by the police in search of incriminating documentation.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=20 April 2017 |title=La UCO busca en OHL, Price Waterhouse Cooper, Indra y otras empresas pruebas de la posible financiación ilegal del PP |url=http://www.lasexta.com/noticias/nacional/guardia-civil-registra-sede-constructora-ohl-madrid_2017042058f890380cf2ea95b025d6e0.html |language=Spanish |work=laSexta |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> Party veteran and former González's boss [[Esperanza Aguirre]] resigned from her remaining political offices after seeing many of her former close advisers imprisoned or accused.<ref>{{cite news |last=Casqueiro |first=Javier |date=24 April 2017 |title=Former Madrid PP leader resigns over latest corruption scandal |url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2017/04/21/inenglish/1492758688_985633.html |work=El País |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Casqueiro |first=Javier |date=25 April 2017 |title=Has Spain finally seen the last of Esperanza Aguirre? |url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2017/04/25/inenglish/1493111041_159486.html |work=El País |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Esperanza Aguirre 2015c (cropped).jpg|175px|thumb|left|PP veteran [[Esperanza Aguirre]] was forced out from politics after her former protégé [[Ignacio González González|Ignacio González]] came involved in the Lezo scandal.]] The leaking of a series of recordings that involved González and various high-ranking PP and government officials—including former [[President of the Valencian Government]] [[Eduardo Zaplana]] and [[Ministry of Justice (Spain)|Justice Minister]] [[Rafael Catalá]]—unveiled a plot from the [[Ministry of the Interior (Spain)|Interior]] and Justice ministries [[Obstruction of justice|to cover-up the scandal]], seriously putting [[judicial independence]] in Spain into question.<ref>{{cite news |last=Águeda |first=Pedro |date=25 April 2017 |title=Las grabaciones a Ignacio González evidencian las maniobras del PP para quitar y poner jueces y fiscales |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Ignacio-Gonzalez-evidencian-maniobras-PP_0_636937525.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Npt stated--> |date=25 April 2017 |title=El SMS de Rafael Catalá a Ignacio González en 2016: "Ojalá se cierren pronto los líos" |url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2017/04/25/58ff2a07e5fdea34438b4615.html |language=Spanish |work=El Mundo |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Hernández |first=Marisol |date=25 April 2017 |title=El ministro del Interior revela que Ignacio González le telefoneó y le pidió tomarse un café |url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2017/04/25/58ff87d0ca47413d3d8b4630.html |language=Spanish |work=El Mundo |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> In one of the leaked recordings, González pointed to a tape that would allegedly show Rajoy receiving bribes from a businessman, and that this would have been used by [[Intereconomía TV|Intereconomía]] CEO [[Julio Ariza]] in the past to blackmail him.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=12 May 2017 |title=Rajoy habría sufrido un chantaje: así lo revelan las conversaciones entre Ignacio González y Zaplana del caso Lezo |url=http://www.lasexta.com/noticias/nacional/rajoy-habria-sufrido-un-chantaje-asi-lo-revelan-las-conversaciones-entre-ignacio-gonzalez-y-zaplana-del-caso-lezo_20170512591581940cf2a1da482d1494.html |language=Spanish |work=laSexta |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref> Concurrently, the anti-corruption chief prosecutor, Manuel Moix—revealed by police wiretaps to have been favoured for the job by Ignacio González before his appointment in February 2017—was accused of trying to stop investigations into the PP graft accusations.<ref name="censure2">{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Sam |date=1 May 2017 |title=Podemos to table no-confidence vote against Mariano Rajoy amid corruption scandal |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/01/podemos-press-no-confidence-vote-mariano-rajoy-spain |work=The Guardian |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Keeley |first=Graham |date=2 May 2017 |title=Anti-corruption chief got top job after fraud suspect put in a good word |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/anti-corruption-chief-got-top-job-after-fraud-suspect-put-in-a-good-word-7v6f5wjvd |work=The Times |location=Madrid |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> José Antonio Nieto, Secretary of State for Security—[[Juan Ignacio Zoido]]'s deputy in the Interior Ministry—came under pressure after he was accused of revealing details of the ongoing investigations to González's brother in a private meeting held on 8 March 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last=Vázquez |first=Ángeles |date=22 April 2017 |title=El hermano de Ignacio González se reunió con el número dos de Interior tras saberse investigado |url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/politica/hermano-ignacio-gonzalez-reunion-numero-dos-interior-investigacion-5989895 |language=Spanish |work=El Periódico de Catalunya |location=Madrid |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Vázquez |first=Ángeles |date=9 May 2017 |title=La fiscalía sospecha de Interior en el chivatazo a Ignacio González |url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/politica/anticorrupcion-apunta-chivada-secretario-estado-seguridad-expresidente-madrileno-6026264 |language=Spanish |work=El Periódico de Catalunya |location=Madrid |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
By mid-May, the string of scandals had splattered [[Cristina Cifuentes]], incumbent President of Madrid, who was accused by the [[Civil Guard (Spain)|Civil Guard]] of having been involved in the contract awarding procedures that led to her party's illegal financing between 2007 and 2012.<ref>{{cite news |last=Águeda |first=Pedro |last2=Pinheiro |first2=Marcos |last3=Precedo |first3=José |date=16 May 2017 |title=La Guardia Civil implica a Cifuentes en la financiación irregular del PP de Madrid |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Guardia-Civil-Cifuentes-PP-Madrid_0_644286065.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> By this time, it was also concluded that Esperanza Aguirre had won the [[Madrilenian regional election, 2007|2007]] and [[Madrilenian regional election, 2011|2011]] regional elections unfairly, with her campaign budgets well above those legally declared, through a system that "hurted political pluralism". Allegedly, these illegal funds would also have been used in Mariano Rajoy's bid for premiership in the [[Spanish general election, 2008|2008 general election]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Águeda |first1=Pedro |last2=Precedo |first2=José |last3=Pinheiro |first3=Marcos |date=16 May 2017 |title=La Guardia Civil concluye que Esperanza Aguirre ganó dos elecciones haciendo trampas |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Guardia-Civil-Esperanza-Aguirre-financiacion_0_644286211.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Olmo |first1=José María |last2=Parera |first2=Beatriz |last3=Fernández |first3=David |date=17 May 2017 |title=Rajoy se presentó a las generales de 2008 con 685.000€ en B pagados por la trama Púnica |url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/2017-05-17/rajoy-punica-lezo-elecciones2008-dinerob-uco-granados_1383672/ |language=Spanish |work=El Confidencial |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> Suspicions of embezzlement in the Community of Madrid reached as far back as 2001, during [[Alberto Ruiz-Gallardón]]'s premiership, whose cabinet at the time was put under investigation by the Civil Guard.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=9 May 2017 |title=El Canal de Isabel II desvió 83 millones a Panamá en la compra de la colombiana Inassa en la época de Gallardón |url=http://www.lasexta.com/noticias/nacional/canal-isabel-gallardon-desvio-millones-panama-compra-colombiana-inassa_20170509591195a40cf22906e6bb0c8e.html |language=Spanish |work=laSexta |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Fernández |first1=David |last2=Parera |first2=Beatriz |last3=Olmo |first3=José María |date=20 May 2017 |title=La UCO investiga a todo el Gobierno de Gallardón de 2001: Cortés, Cobo, Calvo... |url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/2017-05-20/la-uco-cerca-a-todo-el-equipo-de-gallardon-de-2001-cortes-cobo-calvo-mayor-oreja_1385228/ |language=Spanish |work=El Confidencial |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref> In the meantime, a separate investigation by the [[National Police Corps|National Police]] into the ongoing scandals involving the family of former [[President of the Government of Catalonia]] [[Jordi Pujol]] linked former [[Ministry of Employment and Social Security (Spain)|Labour Minister]] Manuel Pimentel and Ignacio López del Hierro, husband of [[María Dolores de Cospedal]]—incumbent [[Ministry of Defence (Spain)|Defence Minister]] and PP Secretary General—to another corruption plot in Africa, with connections to the Lezo Operation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Águeda |first1=Pedro |last2=Precedo |first2=José |date=19 May 2017 |title=La UDEF vincula al marido de Cospedal con la red de los Pujol en África dentro de una trama que desvió 92 millones |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/UDEF-Cospedal-Pujol-Africa-millones_0_645336508.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
As a result of the scandals, and Rajoy's refusal to take any action despite opposition calls, [[Unidos Podemos]] members—comprising [[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]], [[United Left (Spain)|United Left]], [[En Comú Podem]] and [[En Marea]]—announced that they would table a motion of no confidence and would request support from PSOE and other parties.<ref name="censure1"/><ref name="censure2"/> The rivalries between the opposition parties, however, meant that the initiative was unlikely to succeed: PSOE rejected to support the motion and accused Podemos leader [[Pablo Iglesias Turrión|Pablo Iglesias]] of "bad faith" and of interfering within the party's ongoing [[39th PSOE Federal Congress|leadership primary election]], whereas [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Ciudadanos]]—on which the Rajoy government relied for [[confidence and supply]] support—labeled the move as "circus". The [[Basque Nationalist Party]] also voiced its opposition to the maneuver.<ref name="oppositiontocensure"/> Nonetheless, the Socialists were put in a difficult situation, as opposing the motion would see them rallying behind Rajoy's government amid the ongoing scandals and at a time when they were still without a leader, after the [[2016 PSOE crisis|party crisis]] that led to [[Pedro Sánchez (Spanish politician)|Pedro Sánchez]]'s resignation and Rajoy's investiture in October 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last=Buck |first=Tobias |date=27 April 2017 |title=Spain’s far-left opposition calls no-confidence vote in PM Rajoy |url=https://www.ft.com/content/c7af3dc6-2b3e-11e7-9ec8-168383da43b7 |work=Financial Times |location=Madrid |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
==Motion== ===Registration=== [[File:2017MotionPodemosLogo.png|150px|thumb|upright|Logo used by [[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]] to promote the motion.]] The [[Spanish Constitution of 1978]] required for motions of no confidence to be proposed by, at least, "one tenth of deputies"—35 out of 350—and to include "a candidate for the Presidency of the Government". For a motion of no confidence to be successful, it had to be voted favourably by at least an absolute majority (176) in the [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]]. The vote could not be held until at least five days after the motion's registration, but the law allowed for other parties to fill in alternative motions within the first two days.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=27 April 2017 |title=¿Cómo funciona una moción de censura en España? |url=http://www.lasexta.com/programas/al-rojo-vivo/te-explicamos/como-funciona-una-mocion-de-censura-en-espana_201704275901c5dd0cf2461b6deb3557.html |language=Spanish |work=laSexta |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=27 April 2017 |title=Así funciona una moción de censura en España |url=http://www.antena3.com/noticias/espana/asi-funciona-mocion-censura-espana_201704275901d6070cf2461b6deb4f2c.html |language=Spanish |work=Antena 3 |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
On 19 May 2017, [[Unidos Podemos]] formally registered a no confidence motion against Mariano Rajoy, moved by the group's spokesperson in Congress, [[Irene Montero]], and 36 other deputies, with [[Pablo Iglesias Turrión|Pablo Iglesias]] as the party's candidate. The text of the motion opened with the following considerations:<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=19 May 2017 |title=DOCUMENTO - La moción de censura de Unidos Podemos a Mariano Rajoy |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/DOCUMENTO-Unidos-Podemos-Mariano-Rajoy_0_645335685.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
{{cquote|The Spanish Constitution establishes, in its article 113, that the Congress of Deputies may demand political accountability from the Government through the adoption of a motion of no confidence. The circumstances of exceptionality and democratic emergency experienced by Spain as a result of the ''parasitization'' of state institutions by the [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] (PP) demand for us to make use of this democratic mechanism provided for in our Constitution.
The [[Government of Spain]], in the hands of the People's Party, has left citizens on their own by hijacking the institutions and placing them at the service of the defense of their party and of looters of the public treasury. There is no doubt that, from the Government, the PP does not respect the [[separation of powers]] and makes use of the institutions in their own interest. The credibility of Spanish democracy is at stake, both within our country, in Europe and in the rest of the world. A government that acts against the minimum rules of democracy does not represent our people.}}
Podemos candidate Pablo Iglesias invited the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]] to an agreement, but acknowledged that the initiative was likely going to be defeated. Iglesias claimed that he knew he would not "come out as Prime Minister from this vote of no confidence, but it is my responsibility" and reported that "this motion will serve to mark a before and an after and to demonstrate that there is a real alternative to the PP".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gil |first1=Andrés |last2=Riveiro |first2=Aitor |date=19 May 2017 |title=Entrevista - Pablo Iglesias: "No nos da miedo el PP. Si otros se dejan intimidar o comprar, que lo digan" |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/PP-dejan-intimidar-comprar-digan_0_645335769.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!--Not stated--> |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref> Nonetheless, Iglesias acknowledged that the move was not without "enormous risks", as while previous motions of no confidence were also defeated, the one in 1980 was successful in promoting the figure of [[Felipe González]]—leading him to win the [[Spanish general election, 1982|1982 election]] in a landslide—whereas the one in 1987 signaled the twilight of [[Antonio Hernández Mancha]]'s political career.<ref>{{cite news |last=García de Blas |first=Elsa |date=19 May 2017 |title=Iglesias admite los "enormes riesgos" de presentar una moción que no va a prosperar |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/05/19/actualidad/1495183615_321253.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Madrid |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref> The motion promoters held a demonstration in [[Puerta del Sol]], [[Madrid]], on 20 May, where thousands gathered in support of the initiative.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=20 May 2017 |title=Podemos ==Debate== The debate on the motion of no confidence started on 13 June at 9:00 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] with a two-hour-long speech by [[Unidos Podemos]] spokesperson, Irene Montero, and was followed by a surprise intervention from [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]] [[Mariano Rajoy]], who had been widely expected not to participate in the debate. [[Pablo Iglesias Turrión|Pablo Iglesias]]' speech as candidate followed shortly thereafter, with both Rajoy and Iglesias staging a parliamentary duel which lasted for hours.<ref>{{cite news |last=Juliana |first=Enric |date=13 June 2017 |title=Podemos se eleva, Rajoy acepta el envite |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20170613/423375443512/podemos-eleva-rajoy-acepta-envite.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Moreno |first1=José Manuel |last2=Cardenal |first2=Alfonso |date=13 June 2017 |title=Rajoy se ve legitimado por las urnas frente a la España corrupta que dibuja Podemos |url=http://cadenaser.com/ser/2017/06/13/politica/1497380875_264339.html |language=Spanish |work=Cadena SER |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref> Rajoy claimed that "a government of Iglesias would be a punishment for Spain",<ref>{{cite news |last=Mayor Ortega |first=Leonor |date=13 June 2017 |title=Rajoy: "Un gobierno de Iglesias sería un castigo para España" |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20170613/423373711154/mocion-de-censura-rajoy-gobierno-iglesias-castigo.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref> whereas Iglesias reminded the PP about their corruption scandals and offered the PSOE an alliance in the future to bring the PP government down.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mayor Ortega |first=Leonor |date=13 June 2017 |title=Pablo Iglesias tiende la mano al PSOE para "sacar del Gobierno al PP" |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20170613/423371689029/pablo-iglesias-tiende-mano-psoe-sacar-gobierno-pp.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref> The new PSOE spokesperson, [[José Luís Ábalos Meco|José Luis Ábalos]], announced that the PSOE would abstain and that the motion "would not succeed" because "numbers don't add up". He, however, thanked Iglesias "on his tone" and "picked up [Iglesias'] invitation" for an understanding, but did not clarify whether [[Pedro Sánchez (Spanish politician)|Pedro Sánchez]] would try a motion of his own in the foreseeable future.<ref>{{cite news |last=Castro |first=Irene |date=14 June 2017 |title=José Luis Ábalos: "Agradezco el tono y recojo la invitación, pero la moción no va a prosperar" |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Jose-Luis-Abalos-reivindica-PSOE_0_654434722.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!-- Not stated --> |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref>
[[Republican Left of Catalonia|ERC]]'s spokesperson Joan Tardá praised Iglesias for his initiative and announced his party's support to the motion,<ref>{{cite news |last=Mayor Ortega |first=Leonor |date=13 June 2017 |title=Tardà celebra que Podemos crea "en la desobediencia ante la tiranía" |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20170613/423379776992/joan-tarda-debate-mocion-censura-erc-podemos.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref> whereas [[EH Bildu]] announced a 'critical yes' on the grounds that it was "a priority to evict the most corrupt party in Europe from government" while demanding Iglesias his full support to the [[right of self-determination]].<ref>{{cite news |author=EFE |date=13 June 2017 |title=EH Bildu apoya a Iglesias pero le exige que defienda el referéndum unilateral |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20170613/423378433584/eh-bildu-apoya-a-iglesias-pero-le-exige-que-defienda-el-referendum-unilateral.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref>
==Vote== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:98%;" |- | colspan="3" align="center" bgcolor="#C0C0C0"| '''Motion of no confidence'''<br/>[[Pablo Iglesias Turrión]] ([[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]]) |- ! colspan="2" style="width:150px;"| Ballot → ! 14 June 2017 |- ! colspan="2"| Required majority → | 176 out of 350 {{cross|15}} |- ! style="width:1px; background:green;"| | style="text-align:left;"| {{Collapsible list | title = <span style="font-weight:normal;">Yes</span> | • [[Unidos Podemos|UP]]–[[En Comú Podem|ECP]]–[[En Marea|EM]] (67) | • [[Republican Left of Catalonia|ERC]] (9) | • [[Coalició Compromís|Compromís]] (4) | • [[EH Bildu]] (2) }} | {{Composition bar|82|350|green|width=125px}} |- ! style="background:red;"| | style="text-align:left;"| {{Collapsible list | title = <span style="font-weight:normal;">No</span> | • [[People's Party (Spain)|PP]] (134) | • [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Cs]] (32) | • [[Navarrese People's Union|UPN]] (2) | • [[Canarian Coalition|CCa]] (1) | • [[Asturias Forum|FAC]] (1) }} | {{Composition bar|170|350|red|width=125px}} |- ! style="background:gray;"| | style="text-align:left;"| {{Collapsible list | title = <span style="font-weight:normal;">Abstentions</span> | • [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party|PSOE]] (84) | • [[Catalan European Democratic Party|PDeCAT]] (7) | • [[Basque Nationalist Party|PNV]] (5) | • [[New Canaries|NCa]] (1) }} | {{Composition bar|97|350|gray|width=125px}} |- ! style="background:black;"| | style="text-align:left;"| {{Collapsible list | title = <span style="font-weight:normal;">Absentees</span> | • [[Catalan European Democratic Party|PDeCAT]] (1) }} | {{Composition bar|1|350|black|width=125px}} |- | style="text-align:left;" colspan="3"| Sources<ref name="HECongressVotes">{{cite web |url=http://www.historiaelectoral.com/congresovota.html |title=Congress of Deputies: Most important votes |language=Spanish |website=historiaelectoral.com |publisher=Electoral History |accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> |}
==Aftermath== As expected, the motion was defeated on 14 June 2017, having gathered the support of [[Unidos Podemos]], [[Coalició Compromís|Compromís]], [[Republican Left of Catalonia|ERC]] and [[EH Bildu]] for a total of 82 favourable votes and 170 against.<ref name="MotionResult">{{cite news |last=Garea |first=Fernando |date=14 June 2017 |title=Iglesias pierde la moción de censura y solo suma a ERC, Bildu y Compromís |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/06/14/actualidad/1497424691_376661.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref> However, during the debate both Unidos Podemos and PSOE hinted at the possibility of a future understanding that could see them both working in a joint motion.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cortizo |first=Gonzalo |date=14 June 2017 |title=Fracasa la moción de censura contra Rajoy mientras Iglesias piensa ya en la siguiente |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Fracasa-censura-Rajoy-Iglesias-siguiente_0_654434940.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!-- Not stated --> |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref> Such an invitation was offered by Iglesias who, during a reply to PSOE's spokesperson José Luis Ábalos, stated that Podemos would "commit [themselves] with the new PSOE in search of an alternative majority" and urged the Socialists to "work together during the summer to negotiate a motion of no confidence".<ref>{{cite news |last=Riveiro |first=Aitor |date=14 June 2017 |title=Pablo Iglesias emplaza al PSOE a "trabajar una moción de censura en verano" para echar al PP |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Pablo-Iglesias-responde-Abalos_0_654434811.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |location=<!-- Not stated --> |access-date=14 June 2017}}</ref>

{{Sierra Leone Civil War}} The '''Abidjan Peace Accord''' was a treaty signed in [[Abidjan]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]] on 30 November 1996 to try to bring an end to the [[Sierra Leone Civil War]] (1991–2002).<ref name=APA>{{cite web |url=http://peacemaker.un.org/sierraleone-peace-agreement-RUF96 |title=Peace Agreement between the Governement ''(sic)'' of the Republic of Sierra Leone and the RUF/SL (Abidjan Peace Agreement) |publisher=[[UN Peacemaker]]}} (document download required)</ref> The two main signatories were President [[Ahmad Tejan Kabbah]] of [[Sierra Leone]] and [[Foday Sankoh]], leader of the [[Revolutionary United Front]] (RUF) rebel group.<ref name=APA/> However, Sankoh refused to honour the terms of the agreement, and Kabbah was forced into exile by a May 1997 military coup (though he regained power the following year), so the Accord failed to bring about peace.<ref name=Bangura>{{cite journal |last1=Bangura |first1=Yusuf |year=1997 |title=Reflections on the Abidjan Peace Accord |journal=[[Africa Development]] |publisher= |volume=XXII |issue=3/4 |pages= |jstor=43658010|doi= }} Full text available [http://reliefweb.int/report/sierra-leone/unrisd-reflections-1996-sierra-leone-peace-accord here]</ref>
==Background== The civil war began on 23 March 1991, when the RUF attempted to overthrow the government of President [[Joseph Saidu Momoh]]. A [[1992 Sierra Leonean coup d'état|1992 military coup]] saw Captain [[Valentine Strasser]], barely 25 years old, seize power, but the fighting continued. Strasser himself would be ousted by [[Julius Maada Bio]] in 1996. Peace negotiations were pursued intermittently through the regime changes.<ref name=Gberie>{{cite web |url=http://www.c-r.org/downloads/Accord%2009_4First%20stages%20on%20the%20road%20to%20peace_2000_ENG.pdf |title=First stages on the road to peace: the Abidjan process (1995–96) |author=Lansana Gberie |publisher=[[Conciliation Resources]]}}</ref>
On 25 February 1996, delegations from both sides, along with United Nations Special Envoy [[Berhanu Dinka]] and representatives of the [[Organisation of African Unity]] and the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]], met in Abidjan for four days.<ref name=Gberie/><ref name=Mutwol>{{cite book |title=Peace Agreements and Civil Wars in Africa |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vcVq5_LRLsUC&pg=PA219 |publisher=Cambria Press |last=Mutwol |first=Julius |isbn=9781621968542 |pages=219–}}</ref> On 25–26 March, Bio and Sankoh met face-to-face for talks in [[Yamoussoukro]], [[Ivory Coast]], under the auspices of that country's president, [[Henri Konan Bédié]].<ref name=Gberie/><ref name=Mutwol/> Days later, [[Ahmad Tejan Kabbah]] was elected President of Sierra Leone. Kabba and Sankoh met on 22–23 April in Yamoussoukro and agreed to a [[ceasefire]].<ref name=Gberie/><ref name=Mutwol/> Talks continued, though both sides accused the other of breaching the ceasefire.<ref name=Gberie/> In October or November, Kabba again met with Sankoh, this time in Abidjan.<ref name=Gberie/> Finally, on 22 November, the Abidjan Peace Accord was signed, the government having made concessions and the RUF having suffered severe military defeats.<ref name=Bangura/><ref name=Mutwol/>
==Goals== The accord had a broad range of goals, the main ones being:<ref name=APA/> * The armed conflict between the two main signatories was to end "with immediate effect." * A National Commission for the Consolidation of Peace was to be established within two weeks of the signing. * A Neutral Monitoring Group would consist of monitors drawn from the "international community". * All RUF combatants would disarm, and amnesty would be granted them. * Efforts would be made to reintegrate RUF rebels into society. * The government-hired [[Executive Outcomes]] and other foreign troops would leave the country after the establishment of the monitoring group.
==Signatories== *Alhaji Dr. Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, President of the Republic of [[Sierra Leone]] *Corporal Foday Saybana Sankoh, leader of the Revolutionary United Front *[[Henri Konan Bédié]], President of the Republic of [[Côte d'Ivoire]] *[[Berhanu Dinka]], Special Envoy of the [[United Nations]] Secretary-General for Sierra Leone *Adwoa Coleman, representative of the [[Organization of African Unity]] *Moses Anafu, representative of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth Organization]]<ref name=APA/>
==Results== The National Commission for the Consolidation of Peace was set up, but accomplished little or nothing.<ref name=AP>{{cite book |last1=Ayissi |first1=Anatole N. |last2=Poulton |first2=Robin |title=Bound to Cooperate: Conflict, Peace and People in Sierra Leone |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n3plcSNSqLUC&pg=PA39|year=2006 |publisher=United Nations Publications UNIDIR |isbn=9789290451839 |pages=39–40}}</ref> The Neutral Monitoring Group was supposed to number 700, but the RUF objected, proposing it consist of only 120 monitors, and agreement could not be reached.<ref name=AP/> Then RUF spokesmen and supporters of the Commission for the Consolidation of Peace, Fayia Musa, Ibrahim Deen-Jalloh and Philip Palmer, attempted to overthrow Sankoh as leader of the RUF<ref name=AP/> after Sankoh was arrested in Nigeria.<ref name=Hirsch>{{cite book |last=Hirsch |first=John L. |title=Sierra Leone: Diamonds and the Struggle for Democracy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uxyVr8dEUlwC&pg=PA54 |year=2001 |publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers |isbn=9781555876982 |pages=54–56}}</ref> The three were captured by RUF forces, and Sankoh consolidated power in the RUF.<ref name=Hirsch/> A military coup on 25 May 1997 by [[Johnny Paul Koroma]], leader of the newly formed [[Armed Forces Revolutionary Council]], resulted in an alliance with the RUF.<ref name=AP/> This was certainly the death knell for any hope of peace stemming from the Abidjan Accord.

{{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=May 2015}} {{cleanup|reason=inconsistencies in spelling and POV|date=May 2015}} }} [[File:Col Younghusband and Amban.JPG|thumb|[[Youtai]], the Amban of [[Lhasa]], and Colonel [[Francis Younghusband]]]] [[File:49. T'ang Ta-Jên, military Amban of Khotan, with his children and attendants.png|thumb|T'ang Ta-Jên, military Amban of [[Khotan]], with his children and attendants]] '''Amban''' ([[Manchurian language|Manchu]]:{{ManchuSibeUnicode|lang=mnc|ᠠᠮᠪᠠᠨ}}''Amban'', [[Mongolian language|Mongol]]:{{MongolUnicode|lang=mn|ᠠᠮᠪᠠᠨ}} Амбан, [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan]]:ཨམ་བན་''am ben'', [[Uyghur language|Uighur]]:ئامبان་''am ben'') is a Manchu language word meaning "high official," which corresponds to a number of different [[Qing#Bureaucracy|official titles]] in the [[Qing dynasty|Qing]] imperial government. For instance, members of the [[Grand Council (Qing dynasty)|Grand Council]] were called ''Coohai nashūn-i amban'' ([[File:coohai1.png|50px]]) in Manchu and Qing [[Governor-General (China)|governor-generals]] were called ''Uheri kadalara amban'' ([[File:Uheri kadalara amban.png|60px]]). The word ''amban'' was transcribed into [[Chinese language|Chinese]] as {{lang|zh|昂邦}} ({{lang|zh-Latn|ángbāng}}). By far the most known ambans were the Qing imperial residents (Manchurian: [[File:Seremšeme tehe amban.png|60px]] ''Seremšeme tehe amban''; {{zh|t=駐紮大臣}} {{lang|zh-Latn|Zhùzhá Dàchén}}; and Tibetan: ''Ngang pai'') in [[Tibet]], [[Qinghai]], [[Mongolia]] and [[Xinjiang]], which recognized Qing authority, but were not governed as regular provinces and retained many of their existing institutions. The Qing imperial residents can be roughly compared to a European [[Resident (title)|resident]] in a [[protectorate]] (e.g. a British Indian [[princely state]]), the real rapport depending on historical circumstances rather than a general job description for every amban, while his authority often was very extensive, rather like a provincial governor. ==Tibet== {{see also|List of Qing Imperial Residents in Tibet}} The Qing Emperor appointed an amban in [[Tibet]] ({{zh|p=Zhùzàng Dàchén |t=駐藏大臣}}), who represented Qing authority over the Buddhist theocracy of Tibet, and commanded over 2,000 troops stationed in [[Lhasa]]{{Citation needed|reason=source and time period needed for this statement|date=July 2017}}. The chief amban was aided by an assistant amban ({{zh|labels=no |p=Bāngbàn Dàchén |t=幫辦大臣}}) and both of them reported to the Qing '''[[Lifan Yuan]]'''. Their duties included acting as intermediary between China and the Hindu kingdom of [[Nepal]] (Ghorkhas Country); a secretary ({{zh|labels=no |p=Yíqíng zhāngjīng |c=夷情章京}}) dealt with native affairs. Three Chinese commissioners ({{zh|labels=no |p=liángtái |c=糧台}}), of the class of sub-prefects, were stationed at Lhasa, Tashilumbo and Ngari. The Qing imperial resident in Tibet was introduced in 1727 and most ambasa were appointed from the Manchu [[Eight Banners]], a few were Han Chinese or Mongol. The Emperors used ambasa to supervise Tibetan politics, and the [[Qianlong Emperor|Qianlong]], [[Jiaqing Emperor|Jiaqing]] and [[Daoguang Emperor|Daoguang]] Emperors each decreed that the [[Dalai Lama]] and [[Panchen Lama]] were bound to follow the leadership or guidance of the ambasa in carrying out the administration of Tibet. [[Zhao Erfeng]], a Han Chinese [[Eight Banners|Bannerman]], was appointed as Amban of Tibet by the Qing government. He was killed during the [[Xinhai Revolution]] by Chinese Republican Revolutionary forces intent on overthrowing the Qing dynasty. After the fall of the Qing dynasty in 1912, the Manchu Amban Lien Yu and his Chinese soldiers were expelled from Lhasa.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=un88AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA21&dq=atuntze+behead&hl=en&ei=v-gMTrXYAeHr0gH9teCSDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=chinese%20chao's%20indefatigable%20spirit%201906&f=false|title=travels of a consular officer in eastern tibet|author=|year=|publisher=CUP Archive|edition=|location=|page=22|isbn=|pages=|accessdate=2011-06-28}} ==Xinjiang== ===Dzungaria=== ===Altishahr=== [[Altishahr]], meaning six cities, consisted of [[Uyghur people|Uyghur]] cities of Yarkand, Kashgar, Khotan, Kuche, Aksu, and Yangi Hisar (or Ush-Turfan).{{cite web|title=Altishahr |url=http://onlinehistories.ssrc.org/centralasia/glossary/default.aspx |work=On-line Histories of Central Asia |publisher=The Eurasia Program, Social Science Research Council |accessdate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322030513/http://onlinehistories.ssrc.org/centralasia/glossary/default.aspx |archivedate=22 March 2012 }} The Qing dynasty's wars with the [[Zunghar Khanate]] pushed them into the area and by 1759 they had obtained control of this region. After the [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|rebellion]] of [[Yakub Beg]], Altishahr was incorporated into the administration of Xinjiang, which became a formal province in the Qing empire in 1884. Between 1761 and 1865, the [[Qing]] Empire appointed an imperial resident (Manchu: [[File:h amban1.png|35px]] ''hebei amban''; Chinese: ''zǒnglǐ huíjiāng shìwù cānzàn dàchén'' 總理回疆事務參贊大臣) to Altishahr, which today forms part of southern [[Xinjiang]]. The imperial resident, who resided in [[Kashgar]], [[Aksu Prefecture|Ush Turfan]] or [[Yarkant County|Yarkand]] and exercised Qing authority over the region. The imperial resident was controlled with local imperial agents (Manchu: [[File:b amban1.png|60px]] ''Baita icihiyara amban''; Chinese: ''Bànshì dàchén'' 辦事大臣), who were sent to most important cities in the region, where they ruled in conjunction with the local officials (Uighur:ھاكىمبەگ ''hakim beg'', Chinese: 阿奇木伯克), who were given ranks in the Qing civil service and were ultimately accountable to the imperial agent. ==Urga == In the holy city of [[Ulan Bator|Urga]], an amban (Mongol: {{MongolUnicode|lang=mn|ᠬᠦᠷᠢᠶᠡᠨ ᠦ
ᠠᠮᠪᠠᠨ
ᠨᠣᠶᠠᠨ}} Хүрээний амбан ноён, Chinese: 庫倫辦事大臣 ''Kùlún bànshì dàchén'') was stationed in order to assert Qing control over the [[Mongolia|Mongol]] dependencies. He controlled all temporal matters, and was specially charged with the control of the frontier town of [[Kiakhta]] and the trade conducted there with the Russians. Urga was also the residence of the [[Jebtsundamba Khutuktu]], who was the [[Buddhism in Mongolia|spiritual head]] of the Mongol [[Khalkha]] tribes. The Khutuktu ranked third in degree of veneration among the dignitaries in the [[Tibetan Buddhism]], after the [[Dalai Lama]] and [[Panchen Lama]]. He resided in a sacred quarter on the western side of the town and acted as a spiritual counterpart of the Qing amban. After the fall of the Qing dynasty in 1912, the Manchu amban was expelled by Mongol forces, fleeing to [[China proper]] via Russia. ==Manchuria== In the early Qing, the word ''amban'' was also used in the title of the military governors (昂邦章京, ''angbang-zhangjing'', which is a transcription of the Manchu ''amban-jianggin''; R.L. Edmonds translates the title in English as "military deputy-lieutenant governor"{{cite book|title=Northern Frontiers of Qing China and Tokugawa Japan: A Comparative Study of Frontier Policy|first=Richard Louis|last=Edmonds|publisher=University of Chicago, Department of Geography; Research Paper No. 213|isbn=0-89065-118-3|year=1985|page=113}}) in the northeastern provinces of the Qing Empire, viz. [[Jilin]] and [[Heilongjiang]]. The first ''amban-jianggin'' appointed in the region was the [[Ninguta]] garrison commander [[Sarhuda]], who became the ''amban-jianggin'' of [[Ninguta]] in June 1653.[http://iea.cass.cn/jianbao/F000252.doc 吉林省历史沟沉]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (An exploration of the history of Jilin Province). There is also {{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ==See also== * [[Qing dynasty in Inner Asia]] * [[Lifan Yuan]] == References == === Citations === {{Reflist}} === Sources === * Ho, Dahpon David. "The Men Who Would Not Be Amban and the One Who Would: Four Frontline Officials and Qing Tibet Policy, 1905-1911." ''Modern China'' 34, no. 2 (2008): 210-46. * Kolmaš, Josef. ''The Ambans and Assistant Ambans of Tibet, Archiv Orientální. Supplementa 7.'' Prague: The Oriental Institute, 1994. * Mayers, William Frederick. ''The Chinese Government: A Manual of Chinese Titles, Categorically Arranged and Explained, with an Appendix.'' 3rd edition revised by G.M.H. Playfair ed. Shanghai: Kelly & Walsh, 1897; reprint, Taibei: Ch'eng-Wen Pub. Co., 1966. * Newby, Laura J. ''The Empire and the Khanate: A Political History of Qing Relations with Khoqand C. 1760-1860.'' Leiden; Boston: Brill, 2005. * [[Jerry Norman (sinologist)|Norman, Jerry]]. ''A Concise Manchu-English Lexicon.'' Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1978. * Shakya, Tsering. ''The Dragon In The Land Of Snows'' (1999) Columbia University Press. {{ISBN|0-231-11814-7}} == External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Ambans}} {{Qing dynasty topics}} [[Category:Manchu words and phrases]] [[Category:Gubernatorial titles]] [[Category:Qing dynasty]] [[Category:Mongolia under Qing rule]] [[Category:Political office-holders in Tibet|.]] [[Category:Foreign relations of the Qing dynasty]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Tibet]]
